text: every Thursday night in freeze Virginia
a group of musicians gather at the
century-old freeze theater once a movie
house the films have been replaced by
music no one dresses for the occasion
and no one reads cheap music but the
sound is joyful authentic and brilliant
Freese's stop and what most Virginians
know is the crooked road it's 300 miles
of country highways linked together by a
common musical history the sound here is
old time in bluegrass it evolved from
the tunes carried by 18th and 19th
century Scotch Irish and German
immigrants who traveled down wagon
trails from Pennsylvania these old
country roads are still steeped in the
tradition of making instruments from
guitars and banjos to mandolins and
fiddles and those that make them called
luthiers are revered here
perhaps no one more so than Wayne
Henderson you know my dad was another
knife at my grandpa's late overtime
banjo and it was just something was just
the way alive for us
each June he runs an annual guitar
festival in Grayson Highlands State Park
mr. Henderson is one of the many along
the crooked road who strived to maintain
the region's rich tradition of old-time
music over in Floyd about an hour and a
half from Freese the Friday night
Country Store Jamboree draws hundreds
each week packing the house with all
time flatfoot dancers who wear double
tap shoes that provide a syncopated
rhythm
Jackie Martin a local dancer explained
what draws the crowd
it's just our heritage around here and
just brings a lot of joy today everybody
it's who we are and what we are and and
it's precious to us but perhaps the most
storied venue on the road is the Carter
Family fold
that's where Johnny Cash played his last
concert each Saturday night at the fold
old-time groups take the stage and
dancers fill every seat music is in the
blood here taught to children and
celebrated in a new permanent exhibit at
the Blue Ridge Music Center their
visitors can trace the history of the
banjo and the dulcimer and meet about
how music has kept these communities
dancing for generations
for the New York Times this is Sara
Wylde
